recipe.title: How to Make a Chocolate Bar

procedure.summary: Blend ½ cup (60g) of cacao nibs into a paste.
procedure.description: Cacao nibs have a dense, rich, chocolate flavor, and will give you the best homemade chocolate as a result. Pour the cacao nibs into a food processor or blender and turn it to the highest setting. Continue processing the nibs until they are ground into a fine paste. Cacao nibs can be difficult to find in some parts of the world but should be available at your local health food stores or online. If you can’t find cacao nibs, try a different method to make your own chocolate bars.

procedure.summary: Add ¼ cup (25g) of powdered sugar to the cacao.
procedure.description: Pour the powdered sugar into the food processor or blender with the cacao paste. Turn the blender or processor to a medium speed until the two ingredients are fully mixed. If you prefer a sweeter chocolate bar, add a little more powdered sugar. Anywhere between ¼ cup (25g) and ½ cup (50g) will keep the consistency of your bar right while changing the sweetness.

procedure.summary: Melt ¼ cup (40g) of cocoa butter.
procedure.description: Scoop around ¼ cup (40g) of cocoa butter into a small bowl and melt it, either in the microwave or over a double boiler. Make sure the butter is entirely melted. Cocoa butter should be available from your local gourmet or health food store. It is also available online.

procedure.summary: Pour the melted cocoa butter into the food processor.
procedure.description: Leave the food processor or blender running and start slowly streaming in the melted cocoa butter. Keep blending until all of the ingredients are combined and you have a smooth mixture. The amount of cocoa butter needed will vary based on the amount of powdered sugar used in the recipe. Add it in slowly until you reach a smooth texture that will be just pourable.

procedure.summary: Pour your chocolate mixture into molds or onto a baking sheet.
procedure.description: For a traditional chocolate bar, pour your chocolate onto a parchment paper lined baking sheet and spread to all corners. If you want more interesting or varied shapes, look for silicone or chocolate molds available from homeware and cooking stores.

procedure.summary: Freeze your chocolate for 3 to 4 hours or until completely firm.
procedure.description: Carefully transfer your chocolate molds to the freezer and leave for several hours or overnight. This will freeze the cocoa butter and solidify your mixture into chocolate bars.

procedure.summary: Remove the chocolate from the molds and store for up to 3 weeks.
procedure.description: Once the chocolate is completely solid, remove the mold from the freezer and pop the chocolates out. Transfer to a plastic bag or container and store for up to 3 weeks. As cocoa butter has a melting point around 36 °C (97 °F), it is best to store it in the refrigerator until you are ready to eat it. This will give you a similar snap to processed chocolate.
